questions.question: If you put your …………………….. foot forward you’ll succeed in the interview.
questions.description: To put your best foot forward is to make a favorable impression.

questions.question: She has an interview tomorrow and she is pulling her …………………………. out.
questions.description: To pull your hair out is to be very worried about something

questions.question: Before accepting the job offer, she made it clear that she must have a free …………………………
questions.description: When you have a free hand you have the power to do what you want.

questions.question: He has no …………………………….. in running the company.
questions.description: To have a hand in something is to be involved in it.

questions.question: In almost all societies rich people still have the …………………………. hand.
questions.description: To have the upper hand is to have power and control over someone or a situation.

questions.question: The robbers were caught …………………………… while trying to sell the stolen goodies in the market.
questions.description: To get caught red-handed is to get caught while doing something illegal or wrong.

questions.question: The old man and his sons work hand in ……………………………..
questions.description: When two people are hand in glove, they have an extremely close relationship.

questions.question: He got his ……………………… rapped for talking too much in the class.
questions.description: To rap someone’s knuckles is to give him a light punishment so that he wouldn’t repeat the same offence.

questions.question: So it is your debut tonight. Break a …………………………..
questions.description: It is a phrase used to wish someone good luck.

questions.question: Don’t believe what he says. He is just pulling your …………………………..
questions.description: To pull someone’s leg is to subject him / her to a playful joke or hoax.

questions.question: She thought she had got that role but in the end they chose to cast someone else. There’s many a slip twixt .......................................... and lip.
questions.description: This is an expression used to imply that things can wrong at any time.

questions.question: That thought had never crossed my ……………………………
